sources.text: Scattergood, Thomas (1748-1814). Thomas Scattergood was the son of Joseph and Rebecca Scattergood of Burlington, N.J. He became a prominent Philadelpia Friend. He was in Europe from 1794 to 1800.
sources.citation: Dictionary of Quaker Biography, Haverford College

sources.text: p. 146. The Friends' Asylum, as its name suggests, was, like its inspiration, a Quaker foundation. The prime mover in the enterprise was Thomas Scattergood, who had visited the York Retreat during an extended religious visit to England between 1794 and 1800.
sources.citation: Scull, Andrew, ed., Madhouses, Mad-Doctors, and Madmen, 1981

sources.text: p. 252. Thomas Scattergood, a minister, a member of the Northern district Monthly Meeting, deceased the 24th of the 4th month, 1814, in the 66th year of his age.
sources.citation: Philadelphia Yearly Meeting minutes, 1799-1827, via Ancestry.com search, March 29, 2021

biogHists.text:
Thomas Scattergood (1748-1814), Quaker minister, was the son of Joseph and Rebecca (Watson) Scattergood of Burlington, New Jersey. In 1772, he married Elizabeth Bacon (d. 1780), and in 1783, married Sarah Hoskins (1751-1832). He traveled extensively in the ministry in North America and Great Britain, spending six years in the latter (1794-1800). During his travels in the American South, he spoke out against slavery.

From the description of the Scattergood Family Papers, 1681-1909 (Haverford College).

relations.note: Thomas Scattergood was cousins with Samuel Allinson. Scattergood's father Joseph was the brother of Allinson's mother Elizabeth.

relations.content: Asylum for the Relief of Persons Deprived of the Use of Their Reason (Philadelphia, Pa.)
Monthly Meeting of Friends of Philadelphia for the Northern District
relations.note: Thomas Scattergood was a minister of the Northern District Monthly Meeting.

relations.content: Philadelphia Yearly Meeting of the Religious Society of Friends. Indian Committee

relations.note: Thomas Scattergood's son Joseph married William Rogers's daughter Ann.

resource.title: Scattergood Family papers
resource.abstract: Correspondence, illustrations, marriage certificates, legal and business related papers, photographs, poetry, facsimiles, and other misc. papers related primarily to Thomas Scattergood family of Philadelphia. Correspondence includes approx. 320 letters (1781-1814) of Thomas Scattergood (1748-1814) to family and friends discussing spiritual matters and his travels in Great Britain, New England, North and South Carolina, Virginia, etc.; approx. 250 letters (1781-1814) to Scattergood discuss spiritual matters and Friends' activities, correspondents include Jonathan Binns, Josiah Bunting, John Cox, William Dillwyn, Henry Drinker, William Forster, Susanna Horne, Rebecca Jones, John Pemberton, Joseph Scattergood, Rebecca Scattergood, Rachel Smith, and others; 36 letters (1784-1798) of Sarah (Hoskins) Scattergood to her husband, Thomas Scattergood; approx. 52 letters (1729-1864) of various Friends (chiefly with Hoskins family members), correspondents include John Hoskins, Nicholas Waln and others; extracts (1822-1857) from letters and papers of William Scattergood (1804-1857). Scrapbook of Mary (McCollin) Scattergood, containing illustrations and portraits of Biblical and Quaker subjects, famous people and places; scrapbook (1681-1903) of Alfred G. Scattergood containing letters (includes letters of Thomas Scattergood (1668-1745) to his son Joseph), marriage certificates and other documents of Scattergood and related families, as well as facsimiles, broadsides and other papers related to Quakers; misc. family papers include marriage certificates, photographs, poetry, etc.
resource.extent: 2.5 Linear Feet, ca. 768 items (in 9 v. and 1 box)

                     <title>Letters, 1793-1840.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection includes letters received by Rachel Hunt and her husband, John. Among these are letters from other Quaker ministers on the topic of Quaker spirituality. A letter from Rachel Hunt's brother, John Gibbons, discusses the issue of self will in religion. Other correspondents include Thomas Scattergood, Mary S. Lippincott, Edward Hicks, and Jesse Kersey. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Swarthmore College</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Briggs, Nathaniel.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Rodman, Sarah, 1764-1793.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Chaloner, Job.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Bringhurst, John, d. 1795.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Papers, 1783-1802.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>In a note written in 1802, Bringhurst states he had made holograph copies of letters written to other Quakers about correct religious and moral thinking and these he now wishes to preserve for his children's use after his demise. Letters are to Thomas Pole, Abraham Barker, Nathaniel Briggs, Sarah Rodman, Job Chaloner, John Bringhurst, Job Scott, and George Dillwyn, and are written between 1783 and 1795. Bringhurst counsels Briggs against the slave trade; mentions important work of women ministers to Rodman; mentions Geo. Dillwyn, Wm. Savery, Job Scott, Thos. Scattergood to Chaloner; describes the ministerial visit of Thos. Scattergood and Josiah Bunting to the Southern states to Job Scott; speaks of Samuel Emlen's pending visit to France and of Anthony Benezet to Dillwyn. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Haverford College Library</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Papers, 1783-1802.
resource.abstract: In a note written in 1802, Bringhurst states he had made holograph copies of letters written to other Quakers about correct religious and moral thinking and these he now wishes to preserve for his children's use after his demise. Letters are to Thomas Pole, Abraham Barker, Nathaniel Briggs, Sarah Rodman, Job Chaloner, John Bringhurst, Job Scott, and George Dillwyn, and are written between 1783 and 1795. Bringhurst counsels Briggs against the slave trade; mentions important work of women ministers to Rodman; mentions Geo. Dillwyn, Wm. Savery, Job Scott, Thos. Scattergood to Chaloner; describes the ministerial visit of Thos. Scattergood and Josiah Bunting to the Southern states to Job Scott; speaks of Samuel Emlen's pending visit to France and of Anthony Benezet to Dillwyn.

                  <name>
                     <namePart>Baldwin, Elizabeth J. (Elizabeth Janney),</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Janney, Mahlon, 1731 or 2-1812.</namePart>
                     <role>

                     <namePart>Janney, Sarah, b. 1734.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Scattergood, Thomas, 1748-1814.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Bunting, Josiah, 1734-1813.</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre">Creator</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Janney papers, 1763-1932, bulk 1763-1823.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>This collection primarily includes correspondence of Mahlon and Sarah Janney. These letters relate mainly to family and local news of Loudon Co., Virginia. One letter, written by Thomas Scattergood and Josiah Bunting, provides a brief account of their travels as Quaker ministers. Also included are unsigned fragments, one of which provides an account of a visit to Virginia Yearly Meeting, and another of which concludes a poem addressed to Richard Mott. Also included are notes from the collector, Elizabeth J. Baldwin, on her family history. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Swarthmore College</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Janney papers, 1763-1932, bulk 1763-1823.
resource.abstract: This collection primarily includes correspondence of Mahlon and Sarah Janney. These letters relate mainly to family and local news of Loudon Co., Virginia. One letter, written by Thomas Scattergood and Josiah Bunting, provides a brief account of their travels as Quaker ministers. Also included are unsigned fragments, one of which provides an account of a visit to Virginia Yearly Meeting, and another of which concludes a poem addressed to Richard Mott. Also included are notes from the collector, Elizabeth J. Baldwin, on her family history.

resource.title: John Hunt papers, 1770-1828.
resource.abstract: John Hunt kept a diary for more than 40 years, recording Quaker concerns and daily events. This collections consists primarily of the manuscript journal, 1770-1800; fragments of 1805, 1806 & 1808; and 1814-1824. Of particular interest are the visits of prominent Quakers, including Elias Hicks and Jonathan Evans. There is also an account book, some correspondence received, and other miscellaneous materials. Correspondents include Ann R. Matlack, Asa Matlack, Elizabeth A. Lippincott, John Cox, Joseph Foulke, and Josiah Roberts.

nameEntries.original: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College
